ratings.comment: You can tell he is passionate about what hes teaching, but his lectures arent recorded to review later, and he pretty much only grades his exams and discussions.

Professor Nesper is definitely a character and can be quite funny sometime. He's really passionate about what he teaches, and if you go into it with an open mind and are ready to think critically, this class is great. It really helped me thing more broadly. My one critique is that his grading is a bit ambiguous, but it's definitely manageable.

Larry is very passionate about what he teaches, but doesn't make sense half the time. It's super easy to get him off topic and discuss random things which is great, but he doesn't tell you what is expected on tests. There's a lot of reading and he doesn't outline what the grading rubric is. Doesn't put any grades on learn@UW which is annoying

The grading criteria was very unclear. However, the material discussed in class was extremely interesting and broad. I walked away from this class having read a wide variety of texts, which are applicable to many subjects. If you don't care about getting an A, this class is a must take.

I never understood what we were talking about and none of the lecture time was actually used to explain concepts or make anything clearer. The professor teaches cultural anthropology but uses almost no examples and literally everything is just theory. Definitely regret taking this class

I am an Anthropology major and took both Nespers Anthro 300 and 314 classes. Nesper is a poor but passionate lecturer that will have you endlessly staring down the clock. He is a terribly unfair grader and if he does not like you, you will not do well. Make sure to participate! I would never recommend any of his classes, but if you do- Good Luck!!

Are you sincerely interested in coming out of college with knowledge that will be respected by other academics?  If yes, take his classes.  They will challenge you to think and learn like an academic.  No computers in class should mean you are engaging in the material.   If you are an in experienced essay writer go to office hours.

Absolutely anti-technology which is frustrating. He is also an unfair grader. You can write basically the same thing as someone else but receive a full letter grade lower. I got a C on the bluebook midterm and asked him for feedback and he told me that all of my concepts and ideas were correct, but he didn't like some of the word choices I used.

Lectures and assignments aren' structured and pretty vague.  Most importantly is, as long as you come to class and participate in class, group activities, and discussion you'll do just fine. His grading is pretty easy on the writings and exams.

Ek! No technology whatsoever! But goes through slides quickly and doesn't post them either. Talks alot and sucks at keeping time. Even if he ran out of things to talk about he wouldn't let class out early so you're stuck being bored w/o tech for another 30 min sometimes. Very vague and assignments are pointless. 2 papers both take home!

Dr. Nesper can be very hard to read at first. He comes off as sort of intimidating, but if you read the material he assigns and raise your hand in class to say something at least halfway intelligent he will really appreciate it! Go to lecture, take notes, and pay attention to what he says about different ethnographers and anthropologists.
Thought provoking. Interactive. MUST DO THE READINGS. Go to office hours.

Dr. Nesper is great! I loved his class; he was really knowledgeable and passionate about what he taught. I would love to take more courses in this vein. However, this is not a good course to take if you have no interest in the subject material. If you do the readings & come to lectures you should be able to do fine. There are few assignments.

Professor Nesper is very passionate about his teaching, but it is a bit hard to follow what it is he's trying to say. I didn't know what i was supposed to be learning until about mid semester. Very few graded items so you have to do a stellar job on all of them to get a good grade. You HAVE to go to lecture if you want to pass this class.

Nesper is one of my favorite professors. He is passionate about the topic and he really cares about your understanding. I've heard a lot of people speak poorly of him and I think it's because they didn't care about the class and IT SHOWED. If you come to class and participate, you do well. Easy as that.

Take this class! Prof Nesper assigns a lot of reading, but most of it is fascinating. It is very important that you keep up with the readings. Lectures are unconventional; most of them turn out to be discussions! This course may be more difficult for students that aren't familiar with basic anthropological theory. I really enjoyed this course!

Anthro of Law with Nesper was a fantastic combination of legal studies and anthropology. I was enthralled with the class throughout the semester and found Nesper to be a very knowledgeable and kind professor. Although he can seem intimidating, he is very helpful and willing to discuss anything with those willing to talk with him.
Would not recommend this class! He was very unclear about assignments and exams and turned an interesting topic into a boring one with his tideous lectures.

I was very interested in this course (Indians of Wisconsin) and fairly knowledgeable going into the class.  He did talk about a couple current issues, he mainly spoke of the WI tribes as ancient entities and lectured with a huge emphasis placed in anthropology.  He barely followed the syllabus.  Very disappointed in the way the course was taught.
Very knowledgeable, and really cares a lot about the subject matter. Lectures were clear and engaging, and exams and essay were quite easy. A great ethnic studies class.

TESTS are very hard. Even the TAs could not really help us prepare for them. So many readings and random obscure questions on the test. I liked my TA a lot, lectures were actually very interesting IMO, I did well on the fieldwork paper and I got a B overall. But yes the in class tests are VERY hard.

Worked my ass of for an AB. Field work papers were graded unfairly--different TAs gave weight to what they thought was important. Many other ethnic studies classes have better grading curves. Lectures were thought provoking at times and boring for the rest. Discussions did not relate to lecture, TAs not helpful. DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS.

hands down the worst professor and class ive ever taken. avoid at all times. there is definitely an easier ethnic studies class out there. everything was completely nonrelated between lectures discussions and readings. dont bother reading either

Lectures were very disorganized. Mandatory discussions barely covered any test material. My TA was incompetent & rude. The fieldwork essay was absolute garbage: poorly explained and harshly graded. I read every page assigned, studied adamantly for the tests, and ended up with a C. Avoid this class. I hope I never endure another as terrible as this.

Professor Nesper is easily the worst teacher I have ever had to endure. His lectures all seemed to be 50 minutes of complaining about the world and he frequently misused words and provided embarrassingly bad examples. Due to this professor my opinion of anthropology as a whole has been disgraced. DO NOT TAKE ANY CLASS WITH THIS PROFESSOR!
Unless you want your GPA to drop heavily, avoid taking this class with this teacher. By far worst class/professor Ive taken/had at Madison.

This professor was absolutely useless. Went on ramblings that had nothing to do with the course material whatsoever. Did not allow any study guides or TA's to answer questions before AND DURING midterms/final. Was not personable in office hours. Absurd amounts of reading that were not addressed at all. Avoid this profesor/class at all costs.

Unexpectedly difficult class, especially for an intro level course. Very hard to figure out what will be on the exams, and professor/TAs do not elaborate. Field work project was harshly graded, poorly explained, and the rough draft is only read by two other people in the class (who also do not know what the TAs are looking for) wouldn't recommend

Horrible class. He gave no info for the midterm and there was over 700 pages of reading that was fair game so it made extremely tough to study. I studied forever and still got a bad grade. TA is horrible as well, graded the paper ridiculously hard for no reason. Avoid it for ethnic studies. The previous professor was much better

Awful! I studied hard and got a C on the first test. Worked very hard on a paper..got and F because of things like "I've" instead of " I have", peer editing, etc. He's pompous and doesnt do anything to help you do well in the class. Friend last semester had a DIFFERENT professor and aced the course. That will not be happening with Nesper.

This class has some interesting topics. However,no clarity on assignments. No help from TA at all. TA looks uninterested and bored. The grading system does not make any sense. Honestly, teaching should not be this way

Nesper knows his stuff, but he is very unapproachable and intimidating and the lectures seem like they're completely random. I would highly recommend not taking this class for ethnic studies. The readings are unneccessarily difficult and take forever to get through and he gives very little info about midterms. Unless you have to, don't take it.

Larry Nesper is the most pretentious professor I've ever had at this university. He took an intro level anthro class and made it into an intense graduate-level seminar on Indian law. The books he assigns (one of which he authored) are not written at the undergraduate level. Be warned. Take a different ethnic studies course.

Nesper is the worst professor I've ever had. Taking his Am Ind 314 class was the biggest mistake of my college career. Unless you're really willing to put in the work, or an anthropology major, your chances of getting over a C are not good. I took this for ES requirement and got the lowest grade of my college career. Awful.

Nesper is the worst professor I've ever had. Taking his Am Ind 314 class was the biggest mistake of my college career. Unless your really willing to put in the work, which maybe if you're an anthro major you are, your chances of getting over a C are not good. I took this for ES requirement and got the lowest grade of my college career. Awful.

Other ratings are pretty much on the ball... Guy is all over the place and dear god you MUST do the readings no matter how confusing some may be, because the tests revolve around them more than the lecture notes. Tests (IDs,SA,Essay) are a sprint for the time period and he is a stickler for time. Only take if you need this for your major.

Nesper usually has well organized classes with helpful slides-and is very knowledgeable about the field. There is a lot of reading for his classes, but if you keep up on that, and attend classes, the exams are pretty easy.

Nesper is unorganized and assigns a lot of readings that are not always discussed in lecture. I did not get the point of this class. He was clearly knowledgeable about Native American tribes but the lack of connection between the articles made this class hard to follow

I was very excited to take this class, but Nesper's teaching style has completely ruined what otherwise is an incredible topic of interest. His lectures are all over the place, he has few slides of any substance,exams are unnecessarily hard and the books offer little history beyond food, clothing and location of these tribes. Not a good class.

There's a lot of reading that you're not going to get by without, but if you just plow through it the exams arent that hard. Theyre short response/essay that really only have one answer for because usually each question is based off one article so it's just a rehash of that article's info/opinion. Overall very broad class, little depth per topic.

Definitely don't take this just for an ethnic studies credit. Beyond that, the exams were unnecessarily difficult, involving open-ended questions that actually required very specific answers. Also he's all over the place during lecture, so be prepared to scramble/scribble a few hours per week. Not recommended.

Only the lowest 5% of class gets D's and F's, so you just have to be better than the worst 5% to get an ok grade. Nesper uses big words (sometimes made up) and speaks as if he were teaching a much higher level class, so be prepared. 3 essay/identification tests make up 70% of grade, 1 map memorization quiz is 15%, + discussion participation is 15%

He's a good speaker and lecturer, uses high level thinking and also demands this from his students. Do NOT take this class unless have strong interest in Indians. Class has weekly readings from books and scholarly articles. Not a class to slack off in. Avoid if just trying to fulfill requirements. Nice curve though (Top 60% of class gets B AB or A)

This class is a good class if you are interested in American Indian issues. If you are just taking if for ethnic studies and have no interest-DO Not! He expects high levels of analysis and thinking, which is really cool if you like the topics, but can be very very boring and challenging if you do not, exams are very tough as well
If you like boring lectures, copious amounts of irrelevant readings, and extremely difficult exams, have I got a class for you! Seriously, don't take it.

Great professor--- knows what he's talking about, and extremely available to meet with students, even though he's a bit intimidating.  You must attend lecture to do well in this course, but that's not terrible news since Nesper is a captivating speaker.
I took his class last year and it was really boring. The exams are really easy and the the readings aren't bad, but the guy is biased, long-winded and makes an interesting topic uninteresting.
great; hard, but I learned SO much!!

Runs upper-division undergrad courses like grad classes; expects research and copious amounts of reading.  He will stretch you to the limit of your ability, though, so if you need to develop research skills he's the one.  He is unusually generous with his time and conscientious, and expects the same from students.

This class is really interesting, however no one makes anything clear.  Assignments are so vague that you have no idea what you should be doing.  Also, some of the TA's are pretty dumb.  My TA once thought out loud that Iowa was the state under Wisconsin.  I thought it was a joke of a class and consisted of way too much ridiculous work.

Nesper is a good professor. He knows his stuff and really cares about his students. The readings are definitely interesting, and all the material relates with KEY TOPICS from lecture. If you know the main ideas from lecture and discussion and apply them to the readings, youll have no problem in this class. I would definitely recomend taking Nesper.
Good teacher. Hope for a good TA though because it's a big class and you might need some clarification.
The reading for this class is very interesting (for the most part). Lectures can sometimes be very self-identifying, but sometimes opinionated. He has vast knowledge in his field.

Larry Nesper is a tool. Lectures consist of him standing infront of the class and talking for 45min. Class topic are very vague and never clearly defined. Project lacks guidelines they pretty much just say go write a paper on fieldwork 60-80 pages of reading per week that is never really covered well in relation to the class. DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS

I really enjoy going to his lectures. They make me question the makeup of my personality. If you are interested in sociology then this is a great course. If you are a good reader the class is incredibly easy but if your not I can see why it is hard because there is a lot of reading invovled. This is a fascinating course.

Professor Nesper seems like a nice guy, but his lectures are so boring and kind of unorganized. I was very interesting in this subject before I took the class, but after all of the boring readings and movies, I have lost all interest. It has the potential to be a great class, but it needs a different professor.

Skim the readings, survive the lectures (they can be exciting but a lot of the time boring, so go with frequent speakers but get notes from others normal notes days), its in AG HALL so hot, cramped 500-person lecture hall... 2 tests on different cultures with easy details (remember stuff and basic concepts and you're fine) BUT BEWARE OF FIELDWORK!

It is absolutely ridiculous that Nesper forces us to write letters for a cause that is biased and that we may not feel passionate about.  It is like forcing us to write a letter to a political figure he endorses! Plus, his lectures are just a series of ramblings, there is no point in going!

I didn't realize when I signed up for this class that there would be field work!  I like Prof. Nesper.  His lectures are interesting, there are a good number of movies and he adds humor.  There's kind of a lot reading, but it's pretty interesting except the Robbins chapters.  Don't read if you're sleepy!

Nesper may go off on tangents during all his lectures, but nonetheless, what he says is very interesting. If you do all readings and generally remember what happened, you should be good for test. Nesper is very enthusiastic, and he definitely throws out some very subtle messages to try to make us better, more conscientious people.
Anyone else as lost as I am?
I found the reading to be the most interesting...lectures and discussions are extremely boring and you take notes on Nesper's personal opinions half the time.  Speak up in discussion!!

Come on, how could you not love this guy?  He applies his academic work to the real world in a meaningful way.  While most anthro profs are ditching class to attend conferences, publish, and schmooze, Nesper is going out of his way to help students who aren't even in his class.
Pay attention to the boring lectures or you will fail the test.
No Comments
